captions.text:
2/3 of people in
the United States

know that we only
use 10% of our brain.

And by "know," I mean are
crazy, horribly, mistaken.

Anthony here for D News, and
according to a brain health

survey from the Michael J. Fox
Foundation, 65% of Americans

think that we only use 10% of
our brains on a daily basis.

It's definitely something
I've heard in my life over,
over and over again.
Wait a minute.
Were those people insulting me?
Here's the deal.
That is false.
It is crazy false.

There's not a part of your
brain that you do not use.

There is no dormant part
with psychic abilities

or the potential to
instantly memorize

anything you see hidden
behind some cranial roadblock
up there.

The human brain is an
incredibly complex organ.

And all its little bits
are highly specialized,

some of them in ways that we are
just beginning to understand.

The myth probably started
through a misquote

of the findings of a
study guide in the 1890s

by William James
and Boris Sidis,

where they attempted to raise
a child prodigy in a way that

would actually accelerate
his intelligence.

After raising the
kid to an IQ of 250,

James said people
only meet a fraction
of their full mental potential.

He just meant we don't challenge
ourselves enough mentally.

It's also possible
that the myth came

from early neurological research
in the 19th or 20th century.

As scientists started digging
around in all those brains,

it seemed like there were bits
that didn't change anything
if they were damaged or removed.

And now, we know
that some areas just

have very subtle and
specialized functions,

stuff you might not be able
to tell is missing right away.

I mean, there's a
part of our brain

that is just dedicated to
making electrical sockets look
like faces.

We also know that the brain
can rearrange and reassign

functions to a
new part of itself
if an old one is damaged.

But it's easy to see
how early data could
have made it seem otherwise.

We've got way better brain
data now, thanks to stuff

like fMRIs and
PET scans that can

show what the whole brain
is up to at any time

down to these tiny
electrodes that

can monitor the activity
of a single cell.

And they all show
the same thing.

Your whole brain is always
worrying and humming
with activity.

Certain sections work harder
than others at certain times.

But except for people with
actual localized brain damage,
nothing is completely dark.

There are some other
things that point
to the myth being wrong too.

I mean, our brain uses 20%
of our body's total energy.

Why would it need so much
if it was mostly dormant?

Also, unused brain cells
actually degenerate.

And autopsies of human
brains don't ever

show large-scale
degeneration that

wasn't caused by
an actual disease.

So no, you are not a
pill or a technique

away from being a
psychically-powered warrior.

But the real unmangled
quote from William James
is still true.

Most of us don't meet
our mental potential.

So now that you know that you
can access all 100 billion

of those neurons of yours at any
given time, go out and do it.

I'm going to learn
French this afternoon.

I wonder which part
of the brain is

responsible for unhealthy
levels of optimism.

Hey, what do you want to
know about the human brain?
Let us know down below.

And we'll answer some of those
questions in future videos.
And subscribe for more D News.

title: Do We Really Use Only 10% Of Our Brain?

comments.text:
Mythologies

Yes, it is an unfortunate myth that got started somewhere down the history line.

That said, some of the things buddy says in this video aren't quite right, imo, re: "psychic abilities," say, and "cranial roadblocks" (both metaphors of sorts).

There are, I believe, things we could possibly do, know, or understand, but are prevented from merely by mundane beliefs and status quo experiences: acceptance of collective "mob mentalities"--and our immersion and participation therein--is both a disinhibitor and an inhibitor of our possible behaviours and experiences, I reckon.

comments.author: saroj rai

comments.text:
+Nadheer Nazrulla A more accurate interpretation, to be sure. I think many 
still believe it literally, as it's portrayed in hollywood. However, I do 
not think that the "potential" is quantifiable, and thus the 10 percent 
figure is again misleading an unsubstantiated. You could only begin to 
"measure" such a potential by relative comparison in intelligence 
performance experiments, and even that would be subject to modification and 
scrutiny. Do you know of any such experiments, I would be curious to see 
the data, even if it would be somewhat tentative.

comments.author: KARL MARX

comments.text:
+KARL MARX the 10% is conscious however the other 90% is not totally 
unconscious behaviour. For example, we breath unconsciously because the 
medulla oblonganda measures the pH in our blood and determines when we need 
to breath quicker, slower, or at a pace. The heart beats controlled by a 
pacemaker that determines how fast or slow it should beat because of the 
lungs. However, we can consciously breath faster or slower. And we can also 
lower our heart rate because of this. We can also control our dreams some 
times.

comments.author: Sparklez Rainbow

comments.text:
+Ando B You're describing tissue specific transcription of DNA but that is 
in fact included in the ~2% of DNA that codes for proteins. The remaining 
98% (introns) are a legacy of evolution - much of the sequences are now 
defunct. Introns do however contribute to protein synthesis in a more 
subtle way by affecting splicing & processing of RNA.

comments.text:
+Justin Gignac about the 98% thing.If our whole 100% of DNA was used in all 
of the cells we would have a lot of mutations.For example the cells in the 
pancreas make insulin and they contain in there DNA the code of making that 
insulin,but in that same cell they have codes for hair,making brain 
cell,making skin cells,etc(I guess you understand what I mean).But those 
parts are inhibited,so that the particular cell would do only his 
particular function.Each cell just like the pancreatic cells that produces 
insulin uses his part of DNA portions,each cell uses only about 1 or 2 % of 
his DNA to produce only the stuff that the particular tissue needs.
For example a brain cell should not make insulin or testosteron.

comments.text:
98% of the DNA within the human body does not code for the proteins that 
our body uses to make structures such as organs and tissues. Only 2% of the 
entire genome is actually "used" to make these amino acids which build 
proteins. So I was saying, why are they there if they "have no use." I 
truly believe we use 100% of our brains for sure. But the DNA thing is much 
more interesting to me. DNA that doesn't work? I don't thin nature would 
put it there for nothing eh? That's what I meant.
comments.author: Ascending - Into -Tomorrow

comments.author: KARL MARX

comments.text:
I believe that while our brain is "100%" on and functioning, it is similar 
to an idle computer. Sure, you can have it booted up on your desktop 
displaying an image, but are you using 100% of its resources crunching 
numbers or playing games all the time? The short answer is no. It is safe 
to venture that the average person doesn't in fact use 100% of their mental 
capacity, even if they are using 100% of their brain. Herein could lie the 
misinterpretation.﻿

comments.text:
the myth probably came from the fact that we do not use all of our brain at 
once, if you took an image of your brain at any moment only 10% of your 
brains total area is being used at that time, but the next moment a 
completely different 10% of your brain is in use at that moment; so I think 
thats were that came from, you use all of your brain, you just dont use it 
all at once﻿
